title: Majestic Man City should be cherished even if they don't defend Premier League title
text:

If Manchester City do not defend their Premier League title, few should be bothered.

If the points hauls of the previous two seasons prove out of reach this time around, so what?

If Liverpool turn out to be too strong, too consistent, too ruthless, who cares?

Liverpool and City fans, obviously. Before you start.

But as long as Pep Guardiola and his team produce moments and goals such as the one that effectively ended this match as a contest, they should be cherished by all of those without a dog in the fight.

(Image: EMPICS Sport)

Deepish in his own half, an interception falls to David Silva, who cushions a pass into the stride of a gliding Kevin de Bruyne.

On to Gabriel Jesus and across to Benjamin Mendy, a defender strictly in name only. Nothing else.

And then to Raheem Sterling, who can feel the breeze from David Silva’s dart between defenders, sense his senior colleague’s intentions.

A pass lifted exhibition-style and as it drops from the Selhurst air, an over-the-shoulder volley from a player who defines sublime.

It was a thing of beauty. In a tequila sunrise of a strip, it was a cocktail of ingenuity, the type of goal Guardiola must dream about.

(Image: Getty Images)

And it did not just get a ten for artistic impression, unlike the scruffy head and shoulder combination that Gabriel Jesus used for the breakthrough a couple of minutes earlier.

It got a ten for its importance, pretty much guaranteeing a positive result after the Wolves wobble by taking City into the break two to the good.

And no-one was more instrumental in securing that result than Sterling.

If the impudent flick for David Silva’s goal was the party piece of his performance, one breathless dash back to dispossess Wilfried Zaha was the food and drink.

With what passes for City defenders nowadays nowhere to be seen, Sterling’s diligence was as equally as importance as his brilliance.

(Image: PA)

The only blemishes on Sterling’s performance were a couple of snatched finishing attempts, including one particular Raheem-of-old miss from in front.

On that score, he was not alone, and that was the fundamental reason City did not convert their possession superiority into a more emphatic win.

Not that Guardiola will be overly concerned with the spurned chances. He will be relieved with the win, relieved they ended what would, in a Manchester City context, be classed as a goal drought.

When Jesus converted Bernardo Silva’s cross, it ended a period of well over two hours without a Premier League goal for the champions.

That just felt odd.

And while this triumph was something of a canter - although Ederson did have to produce a couple of very decent second half saves - there was still not the total fluidity you come to expect.

(Image: Action Images via Reuters)

Not that Guardiola’s team had to be that fluid against a Crystal Palace team of very limited ambition.

Yes, it is City. Yes, they keep the ball like no other outfit. But there were times when Roy Hodgson’s side looked scared to attack.

Presumably, it was because they feared the sort of counter-attack that produced the Sterling assist and David Silva finish.

When a similar goal was scored in a City training session once, Sterling had to explain to his manager what he meant when he had encouraged a colleague to ‘dink’ it.

Pep certainly knows what it means now, after this matchless assist.

City were not quite back to their dinking best but when they give the game stunning moments like the one they produced here, it does not matter.

In the hurly-burly of the Premier League, a work of art is always welcome.
description: Man City showed some of their brilliance despite wasting chances in a 2-0 win over Crystal Palace at Selhurst Park
